title.native: 超時空要塞マクロス FLASH BACK 2012
title.english: The Super Dimension Fortress Macross: Flash Back 2012

description:
Flash Back 2012 is Minmay's farewell concert. Featuring some of her best songs, the music is performed over various scenes and events taken from the Macross TV series as well as the movie "Do You Remember Love?". Also included is a newly animated closing sequence showing the launch of Misa's colony vessel, the Megaroad-01, into space.

(Source: Anime News Network, edited)
synonyms: Super Dimensional Fortress Macross Flash Back 2012

node.description:
__Height:__ 158cm
__Nickname:__ まりン (Marin)

__[Official Website](https://marimusic.com/)__ | __[Official Blog](https://ameblo.jp/mari-iijima/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Marin_Island)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/mari_iijima_official/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/marimusicvideos/)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/mariiijima)__ | __[Bandcamp](https://mariiijima.bandcamp.com/)__

__Mari Iijima__ is a Japanese actress, voice actress and singer. She is fluent in both Japanese and English. 

She is best known for providing the voice of [Lynn Minmay](https://anilist.co/character/5295) in the classic Japanese anime [The Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088).
Mari reprised her role as Minmay in ADV Films' English-language release of Macross, becoming one of the few Japanese voice actors to ever participate in an English dub.

In 1989, Mari moved to Los Angeles, California where she married James Studer. They had two children (twins), however they ended up separating in February, 2001.

(Source: [Wikipedia (Mari Iijima)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari_Iijima), edited)

__Mari Iijima__ is a Japanese actress, voice actress and singer. She is fluent in both Japanese and English. 

She is best known for providing the voice of [Lynn Minmay](https://anilist.co/character/5295) in the classic Japanese anime [The Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088).

[Website](http://www.mikimotoharuhiko.com/)

A character designer, illustrator and mangaka. He was mostly active in the '80s and '90s, during which he rose to prominence and got recognized as one of the pre-eminent character designers of his time.

Mikimoto attended university at the same time as mangaka [Fujihiko Hosono](https://anilist.co/staff/100345/), as well as [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) and [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/), both of whom he would later collaborate with on the creation of [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) - perhaps Mikimoto's most famous work.

At the time of his debut, he was a fan of [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s and it was showing in his drawings. After a colleague had pointed this out it started bothering him and he went through great effort to gradually establish his own unique visual style which he is known for today. His career as an animator was short-lived as he realized that he was more interested in just drawing pictures rather than moving them around, and naturally shifted his activities from animation to illustrations and manga.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. His projects are usually noted to contain strong themes of love, war, spirituality or mysticism, and ecological concern.

Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Kadutaka_nue)

Kazutaka Miyatake is a visual artist and anime designer known for the mechanical design of the Macross TV series and a number of its continuations from Studio Nue, of which he is a founding member. He has also contributed to the mecha design of other series such as Mobile Suit Gundam SEED Destiny.

Kazutaka Miyatake has designed the spaceships of several famous anime series. His attention to detail and mechanical realism have made his designs still admired upon and used in anime series and related products after several years of their initial appearance.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%BE%BD%E7%94%B0%E5%81%A5%E5%A4%AA%E9%83%8E) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentar%C5%8D_Haneda)

Kentarou Haneda was a Japanese pianist, composer and arranger of popular anime and movies and video game music.

After graduating from the Toho Gakuen School of Music, he taught as a professor at the Tokyo College of Music. He was best known as composer of Wizardry music which was ported to NES and SNES console by Ascii at early 1990, The [Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) series, [Barefoot Gen](https://anilist.co/anime/1824/), Ys Symphony, Symphony Sorcerian and Genso Suikoden Ongaku-shu.

Haneda passed away from liver cancer on June 2, 2007.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Mitsuharu Miyamae is an art director.
